Problem:

Consider an intervention represented by a heat source term \\(S(x,t)\\) introduced at a position \\(x1\\) affecting the system.

If the heat source \\(S(x,t)\\) is introduced at time \\(t1\\) affecting only a local region near \\(x1\\), will the final temperature distribution \\(T(x,T)\\) for \\(T > t1\\) be solely dependent on the properties and initial state of the system without considering the effects of \\(S\\)?
Explanation: The intervention by the localized heat source \\(S(x,t)\\) fundamentally alters the system dynamics at and around \\(x1\\) post \\(t1\\). This change will affect the entire system's temperature distribution over time due to the diffusion, making the end state dependent on both the system’s initial state and the intervention.
